text.p: - An agreement between Slovenian banks cutting interest rates on deposits by about 1.5 percent has come into effect. The country's office for protection of competition said the move was made to stimulate long-term savings.

- Supreme commander of NATO Europe George A. Joulwan starts two-day official visit to Slovenia on Wednesday. He will meet Slovenia's top officials and discuss NATO enlargement and harmonisation of Slovenia's forces with NATO standards.

- Foreign ministry on Tuesday denied news from Albanian radio that Slovenia offered police troops for a joint protection mission in Albania, but said Slovenia was only willing to send some civil monitors to Albania.
- Slovenia's Smelt Olimpija won the second leg of the Euroleague championship quarter-final against Italian Stefanel Milan by 73-69. The two sides will meet again in Milan on Thursday.
- Slovenian Health Insurance Company said on Tuesday that in 1996 it accumulated 168 billion tolars ($1.1 billion), a 21 percent increase from 1995.
- Foreign Minister Zoran Thaler met a Slovenian minority delegation from Austria, before starting a visit to Austria on Wednesday.
- If Slovenia joins NATO in the first round of its enlargement, it would cost the country about $60 to $80 million per year, a study by Slovenia's defence ministry showed.
- Ljubljana's tobacco factory Tobacna Tovarna raised prices of cigarettes by an average seven percent. The company increased prices due to higher prices internationally.

- Thailand's economic delegation starts a two-day visit to Slovenia on Wednesday. Slovenia's 1996 export to Thailand fell by 4.7 percent to $7.4 million compared to 1995, while imports rose five percent to 18.1 million.

- International bankers expect Slovenia to issue up to 400 million marks in Eurobond with a maturity of seven to 10 years. Slovenia is expected to take the decision about the issue by the end of April.
